sections.heading: Agreements; construction of terms
sections.text: When the terms of an agreement have been intended in a different sense by the parties to it, that sense is to prevail against either party in which he had reason to suppose the other understood it.SourceR.S.1867, Code ยง 341, p. 451;R.S.1913, ยง 7909;C.S.1922, ยง 8851;

sections.heading: applied to a land contract where parties intended a different meaning. Edmiston v. Hupp, 98 Neb. 84, 152 N.W. 296 (1915).
sections.text: applied to a land contract where parties intended a different meaning. Edmiston v. Hupp, 98 Neb. 84, 152 N.W. 296 (1915).

sections.heading: to stipulation for settlement of controversy. Southern Realty Co. v. Hannon, 89 Neb. 802, 132 N.W. 533 (1911).
